metadata.case_name: Abdul Sattar Ibrahim Patel v. State of Gujarat

facts.text: Appellant obtained Passport No. 351544 from Government of Pakistan on August 11, 1955, and secured C Visa No. 22144 on October 5, 1957.
Appellant entered India on October 13, 1957, with said passport and C Visa, and obtained residential permit No. 322/57 valid upto December 12, 1957, extended until April 12, 1958.
Appellant did not leave India after residential permit expired on April 12, 1958, contravening cl. 7 of Foreigners Order, 1948.
Appellant charged before Judicial Magistrate Ist Class at Godhra under S.14 Foreigners Act, 1946.
Appellant born in Godhra, parents born in Godhra, brothers living in Godhra, married in Godhra, educated in Godhra preceding marriage.
In March 1948, father-in-law Yusuf Haji Ismail went to Pakistan with appellant's wife.
Appellant went to Pakistan in 1954 to bring back wife, obtained Indian Passport No. C. 041323 dated April 8, 1954.
In Karachi, passport taken away or destroyed by father-in-law, compelling appellant to obtain Pakistani passport to return to India.
Appellant in India until month of August 1954, did not go to Pakistan till then.
Prosecution relied on statements in appellant's application for Pakistani passport admitting Pakistani citizenship, long before 1954.
Trial Magistrate acquitted appellant under S. 251-A (11) CrPC, holding prosecution failed to prove charge beyond reasonable doubt.
State of Gujarat appealed against acquittal; High Court of Gujarat set aside acquittal, convicted under S.14, sentenced to RI one year and fine Rs.1000.
High Court rejected appellant's evidence, found he failed to establish Indian Passport issued in 1954.
Appellant filed list of witnesses on January 21, 1960, including clerk to produce Indian Passport No. C. O. 41323 dated April 8, 1954; witness did not appear.
Supreme Court received record showing appellant applied for passport in March 1954; police sub-inspector enquiry on March 13, 1954, endorsed appellant Indian citizen, no objection to passport.
Family of appellant still domiciled in India, brothers and parents continue to enjoy status of Indian citizens.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant was domiciled in territory of India on January 26, 1950, and satisfied conditions under Art.5, or migrated under Art.7, or voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship under Art.9.
Burden of proof under S.9 Foreigners Act on accused to prove not a foreigner.
Whether appellant was in India until 1954 and obtained Indian passport then.

petitioner_arguments.text: Claimed status of Indian citizen; born, parents born, educated, married in Godhra; in India till 1954; obtained Indian passport April 8, 1954 to fetch wife; forced to get Pakistani passport after it was destroyed.
High Court should not interfere with trial Magistrate's acquittal.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant foreigner and Pakistani national; admitted in passport application; migrated or acquired Pakistani citizenship.

court_reasoning.text: Art.5 requires domicile in India on Jan 26, 1950, plus one of three conditions; Art.7 excludes if migrated after March 1, 1947 to Pakistan; migration requires intention to reside permanently there between March 1, 1947 and Jan 26, 1950.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Basic condition is domicile in India on commencement of Constitution.

court_reasoning.text: Under Art.9 and Citizenship Act, Govt of India decides foreign citizenship acquisition exclusively per R.3 Sch.III; no such decision here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution cannot treat as foreigner without Govt decision.

court_reasoning.text: S.9 Foreigners Act places burden on accused to prove not foreigner notwithstanding Evidence Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Onus on appellant to show Art.5 compliance.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant should get opportunity to prove Indian passport 1954 via additional evidence; records prima facie support; remand for fresh trial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Documentary evidence from official custody would corroborate.

holdings.text: Appellant entitled to opportunity to prove stayed in India until 1954 on Indian passport; case remanded to Magistrate for fresh determination with additional evidence.
Burden under S.9 Foreigners Act on accused; but no Govt of India decision under Citizenship Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Peer Mahomed
precedents_cited.relevance: Migration under Art.7 between March 1, 1947 and January 26, 1950.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Shanno Devi v. Mangal Sain
precedents_cited.relevance: Migration requires intention to reside permanently in Pakistan.

precedents_cited.case_name: Izhar Ahmad Khan v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: R.3 Sch.III Citizenship Act valid; Govt of India exclusively decides foreign citizenship.

precedents_cited.case_name: Government of Andhra Pradesh v. Mohd. Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt of India decision condition precedent for prosecution on loss of citizenship.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Determines citizenship status; Art.5 domicile and conditions; Art.7 migration exclusion; Art.9 voluntary foreign acquisition.

statutes_cited.name: Foreigners Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: S.14 offence of contravention; S.9 burden on accused to prove not foreigner.

statutes_cited.name: Citizenship Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Govt of India decides foreign citizenship acquisition.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside High Court order of conviction and sentence, remanded case to Judicial Magistrate First Class at Godhra to allow parties to lead further evidence, consider whole evidence including new records, and make fresh findings.
outcome.relief_granted: Opportunity to produce additional evidence on Indian passport and domicile.

key_quotes.text: "the onus of proving that such a person is not a foreigner, shall notwithstanding anything contained in the Indian Evidence Act, lie upon such person"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains burden under S.9 Foreigners Act.

key_quotes.text: "migration to which Art. 7 refers must have taken place between March 1, 1947 and January 26, 1950"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of migration under Art.7.

key_quotes.text: "Documentary evidence of this type, coming from official custody, would undoubtedly go a long way in favour of the appellant"
key_quotes.speaker: court
